meanings.definition: To twist or wriggle the body from side to side, especially as a result of nervousness or discomfort.
meanings.sent1: The little boy squirms in his seat during the scary movie.
meanings.sent2: She always squirms when she has to speak in front of a large crowd.
meanings.sent3: The puppy squirms playfully as it tries to escape from being tickled.
meanings.sent4: The caterpillar squirms through the narrow opening of the leaf.
meanings.sent5: The fish squirms vigorously on the hook, trying to break free.

meanings.definition: To cause someone to feel uncomfortable or embarrassed.
meanings.sent1: His teasing remarks always make her squirm with embarrassment.
meanings.sent2: The awkward silence made everyone squirm in their seats.
meanings.sent3: The comedian's jokes made the audience squirm with laughter.
meanings.sent4: The unexpected question made him squirm in his chair.
meanings.sent5: The embarrassing photo made her squirm with discomfort.

meanings.sent1: The squirms of the snake caught the attention of the hikers.
meanings.sent2: The squirms of the worm fascinated the young children.
meanings.sent3: The dance routine included energetic squirms and twists.
meanings.sent4: The caterpillar's squirms helped it escape from the bird's beak.
meanings.sent5: The baby's squirms made it challenging to change the diaper.
